elements.content: Seventeen complexes of 3,5- and 2,4-dinitrobenzoates (L1–L2) with alkali, alkaline, and transition metals have been synthesized and characterized by the single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and thermal studies. Diverse structural topologies have been achieved due to various coordination modes of the benzoates, resulting in five new topologies. Interesting architectures such as zero-dimensional (0D) monomers and paddle-wheel dimers; pseudocubane, double helices, ladders and linear one-dimensional (1D) tapes; pseudodiamondoid and brick-wall type two-dimensional (2D); and chiral three-dimensional (3D) networks were generated. The latter three are formed by the coparticipation of −NO2 groups in the coordination, while 1D complexes are formed by the coordination of water/solvent. Thermogravimetric analysis studies show that the 3D complexes are more stable than 2D; however, 1D complexes become more stable than 2D after the loss of the solvent. The effects of positional isomerism and the nature of the metal ions on the topology also have been observed. The ligands are nonemissive but nine complexes have shown a moderate amount of photoluminescence, owing to the rigidity conferred by the crystal structure of the complex, which largely reduces the radiation less decay and results in enhancement of the intensity of the ligand to ligand charge transfer (LLCT) band. A relatively much larger photoluminescence in the polymeric complex (VIII) of copper(II), however, is a combination of enhanced LLCT due to the double helical 1D crystal structure and chelation enhanced fluorescence (CHEF) phenomenon. A single crystal to single crystal supramolecular transformation of a paddle-wheel complex of copper(II) with guest solvent molecules in the lattice to a desolvated 1D polymer is achieved for the CuL1 complex. Because of self-assembly, six of these complexes crystallize as homochiral, single, double, or triple helical conglomerates, which constitute the most active expression of chirality.

elements.content: Seventeen complexes of positional isomers of dinitrobenzoates unfold a plethora of supramolecular architectures from zero-dimensional monomers and paddle-wheel dimers to pseudocubane, double helices, ladders, and linear one-dimensional tapes to pseudodiamondoid and brick-wall type two-dimensional to chiral three-dimensional networks and show a medium amount of photoluminescence. A heat and desolvation induced single crystal to single crystal transformation and homochiral helical structural motifs also are obtained.

A heat and desolvation induced single crystal to single crystal transformation and homochiral helical structural motifs also are obtained.

elements.content: The concept of “crystal engineering” was revolutionized with the participation of coordination polymers and metallo-supramolecular architectures. The latter are not only designed and developed for their diverse structural aesthetics but also for a variety of their potential applications in catalysis, separation, sensors, adsorption, luminescent materials, magnetism, etc. The glue for the inorganic supramolecular synthesis is the metal–ligand coordinate-covalent bond whose strength and directionality have been thoroughly exploited for engineering various molecular building blocks into diverse supramolecular architectures. The dimensionality of the resulting coordination network can be increased by noncovalent interactions, such as hydrogen bonds, π···π, C–H···π, halogen···halogen, aromatic ring···halogen, and/or other van der Waals interactions. In the coordination polymers the basic building blockscontaining metal ions and organic ligandsassemble infinitely leading to one-, two-, and three-dimensional open networks, commonly known as porous coordination polymers (PCP) or nonporous closed organic–inorganic hybrids.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The concept of "crystal engineering" was revolutionized with the participation of coordination polymers and metallo-supramolecular architectures. The latter are not only designed and developed for their diverse structural aesthetics but also for a variety of their potential applications in catalysis, separation, sensors, adsorption, luminescent materials, magnetism, etc. The glue for the inorganic supramolecular synthesis is the metal-ligand coordinate-covalent bond whose strength and directionality have been thoroughly exploited for engineering various molecular building blocks into diverse supramolecular architectures. The dimensionality of the resulting coordination network can be increased by noncovalent interactions, such as hydrogen bonds, π⋅⋅⋅π, C-H⋅⋅⋅π, halogen⋅⋅⋅halogen, aromatic ring⋅⋅⋅halogen, and/or other van der Waals interactions. In the coordination polymers the basic building blockscontaining metal ions and organic ligandsassemble infinitely leading to one-, two-, and three-dimensional open networks, commonly known as porous coordination polymers (PCP) or nonporous closed organic-inorganic hybrids.

elements.content: For the construction of coordination polymers, under the realm of supramolecular chemistry, the potential of carboxylate-based ligands has been well documented since their polytopic nature and varied coordination modes can facilitate polynuclear coordination complexes without using extra counterions to balance the charge. However, the use of nitro derivatives of aromatic carboxylic acids, as the sole linkers, for the formation of coordination polymers is surprisingly limited (only 14 complexes have been reported; a search based upon CSD), although they have been used rampantly as counteranions. Nevertheless, dinitrobenzoic acids (HDNB) are multifunction ligands that can have variety of binding geometries, both as neutral (HDNB) and in the anionic (DNB–) form (Scheme ). L1 has practically the same disposition of donor groups as benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC), being widely used in forming metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). In those few of L1’s known polymeric coordination complexes it was found that the nitro groups can play a significant role in complexation. Participation of nitro groups along with carboxylate oxygen atoms gives 3D polymeric structures, whereas coordination only through the carboxylate group renders monomeric, dimeric, or 1D polymeric structures. In order to explore new supramolecular architectures formed by employing carboxylate groups, with or without the nitro groups, to explore the effect of positional isomerism of such groups on the resulting coordination networks and their thermal stability and to study the effect or preference of different metal ions for either/or both kinds of groups, here we have employed 3,5-DNB (L1) and 2,4-DNB (L2) anions to form 17 metal complexes with Li(I), Na(I), K(I), Cs(I), Ca(II), Mg(II), Ba(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Ag(I) ions. Various interesting architectures have been build up in the course by invoking coordination as well as hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking interactions (in 2D or 1D CPs only). The Ag(I) and K(I) complexes of L1 reported here are new phases, different than already reported ones, and its Na(I) and Zn(II) complexes have been solved afresh, reviewed, and included for the sake of comparison, for their crystal structures have not been discussed from this point of view.

elements.content: All the reagents were commercially available and used as received. C, H, N elemental analyses were obtained with a CHNS-O analyzer flash-EA-1112 series. The IR spectra of compounds were recorded on a Perkin ELMER FTIR spectrometer in the range 4000–400 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected on a NetzschTG-209 instrument. UV spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu 1700 spectrophotometer in DMSO. Fluorescence studies were done on a Varian fluorescence spectrophotometer. Single crystal structural X-ray diffraction studies were carried out on a Bruker’s Apex-II CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069 Å) at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All the reagents were commercially available and used as received. C, H, N elemental analyses were obtained with a CHNS-O analyzer flash-EA-1112 series. The IR spectra of compounds were recorded on a Perkin ELMER FTIR spectrometer in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected on a NetzschTG-209 instrument. UV spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu 1700 spectrophotometer in DMSO. Fluorescence studies were done on a Varian fluorescence spectrophotometer. Single crystal structural X-ray diffraction studies were carried out on a Bruker's Apex-II CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069 Å) at room temperature.

elements.content: L1 (3,5-DNB) or L2 (2,4-DNB) (1 mmol, 0.21 g) was suspended in a moderate volume of acetonitrile. An aqueous solution of M2CO3 (i.e., Na2CO3, K2CO3, Li2CO3, Cs2CO3) (1 mmol) was added dropwise to this solution and stirred overnight at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to slowly evaporate to give colorless crystals within 1 week (70–78% yield). M.p. > 300 °C.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure

General Procedure for Synthesis of Complexes (I), (II), (III), (IV), (V), (VI), (XII)

 L1 (3,5-DNB) or L2 (2,4-DNB) (1 mmol, 0.21 g) was suspended in a moderate volume of acetonitrile. An aqueous solution of M2CO3 (i.e., Na2CO3, K2CO3, Li2CO3, Cs2CO3) (1 mmol) was added dropwise to this solution and stirred overnight at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to slowly evaporate to give colorless crystals within 1 week (70-78% yield). M.p. > 300 °C.

elements.content: L1 (3,5-DNB) or L2 (2,4-DNB) (1 mmol, 0.21 g) was suspended in a moderate volume of acetonitrile. To an aqueous solution of metal nitrate (1 mmol), (i.e., AgNO3, Cu(NO3)2, Zn(NO3)2, Cd(NO3)2, Ca(NO3)2, Ba(NO3)2, Mg(NO3)2), 0.1 N NaOH was added dropwise, and the solution was stirred well. The solution of L1 or L2 was added to this solution dropwise, and the resulting solution was allowed to slowly evaporate to give green crystals for (XV), (XVI), and colorless crystals for the rest of the complexes within 1 week (70–73% yield). The green crystals of (XV), if removed from the solution and left for a few hours, gave (VIII); leaving (XV) in solution for a long time also yields (VIII), M.p. > 300 °C.

The solution of L1 or L2 was added to this solution dropwise, and the resulting solution was allowed to slowly evaporate to give green crystals for (XV), (XVI), and colorless crystals for the rest of the complexes within 1 week (70-73% yield). The green crystals of (XV), if removed from the solution and left for a few hours, gave (VIII); leaving (XV) in solution for a long time also yields (VIII), M.p. > 300 °C.

X-ray data of all these complexes were collected on a Bruker’s Apex-II CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069 Å) at room temperature except for IV and V, which are done at low temperature (100 K). The data collected by a CCD diffractometer were processed by SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effects and empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS from Bruker. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR-92 and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement methods based on F2, using SHELX-97. The hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from the difference Fourier synthesis and were refined isotropically with distance of 0.82 Å with U iso values 1.2 times that of their carrier oxygen atoms. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically with their U iso values 1.2 times of phenylene carbons. In complex (IV), there is disorder in O2 and O8 nitro oxygen atoms. In complex (V), there is disorder in the O16 atom of the nitro group. This disorder was resolved by splitting each of these atoms in two parts (using PART) with their site occupancy factors and U iso values being refined as free variables with their distances being fixed using DFIX. In complex (VI), the proton of protonated carboxylate group is located from the difference Fourier synthesis and was refined isotropically with a distance of 0.82 Å with U iso values 1.2 times that of its carrier oxygen atom. In complex (XI), the proton of lattice water, which is present at the 4-fold axis, is located from difference Fourier synthesis and refined isotropically with distance of 0.82 Å with U iso values 1.2 times that of its carrier oxygen atom. In complex (XIV), hydrogen atoms of the methyl group of the lattice acetonitrile solvent were fixed geometrically with their U iso values 1.5 times of their carrier carbon and the hydrogen of protonated carboxylate group is located from the difference Fourier synthesis and was refined isotropically with a distance of 0.82 Å with U iso values 1.2 times that of its carrier oxygen atom. All calculations were performed using the Wingx package. Crystal data and structure refinements for complexes (I–XVII), important H-bonding parameters, and bond parameters around the coordination sphere are given as (, respectively).

X-ray Crystallography

X-ray data of all these complexes were collected on a Bruker's Apex-II CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069 Å) at room temperature except for IV and V, which are done at low temperature (100 K). The data collected by a CCD diffractometer were processed by SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effects and empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS from Bruker. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR-92 and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement methods based on F2, using SHELX-97. The hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from the difference Fourier synthesis and were refined isotropically with distance of 0.82 Å with U iso values 1.2 times that of their carrier oxygen atoms. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically with their U iso values 1.2 times of phenylene carbons. In complex (IV), there is disorder in O2 and O8 nitro oxygen atoms. In complex (V), there is disorder in the O16 atom of the nitro group. This disorder was resolved by splitting each of these atoms in two parts (using PART) with their site occupancy factors and U iso values being refined as free variables with their distances being fixed using DFIX. In complex (VI), the proton of protonated carboxylate group is located from the difference Fourier synthesis and was refined isotropically with a distance of 0.82 Å with U iso values 1.2 times that of its carrier oxygen atom. In complex (XI), the proton of lattice water, which is present at the 4-fold axis, is located from difference Fourier synthesis and refined isotropically with distance of 0.82 Å with U iso values 1.2 times that of its carrier oxygen atom. In complex (XIV), hydrogen atoms of the methyl group of the lattice acetonitrile solvent were fixed geometrically with their U iso values 1.5 times of their carrier carbon and the hydrogen of protonated carboxylate group is located from the difference Fourier synthesis and was refined isotropically with a distance of 0.82 Å with U iso values 1.2 times that of its carrier oxygen atom. All calculations were performed using the Wingx package. Crystal data and structure refinements for complexes (I-XVII), important H-bonding parameters, and bond parameters around the coordination sphere are given as  (, respectively).

elements.content: The X-ray crystal structure of [Na(μ6-L1)] n (I) complex is a 3D polymer. The compound crystallizes in a trigonal, noncentrosymmetric P3121 enantiomorphic space group () and has been solved with correct absolute configuration having coordination mode (μ6-κ6, η2:η2:η1:η1) (Scheme (i)). In this complex oxygen atoms of nitro groups also coordinate along with the carboxylate oxygen atoms. A 2-fold axis passes through the carboxylate group and the phenyl ring. The carboxylate group of each L1 bridges four Na(I) ions in a μ4-fashion, and similarly each Na(I) ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygens O1 from four different L1 ligands. The remaining two coordination sites in a distorted octahedron are filled in by the two nonbridging nitro oxygens O2 from yet two different L1 anions. This gives rise to a 3D network as shown down the c axis (Figure a,b), formed by interlinking of the helical chains about the 31 screw axis; one such triple helical chain is shown along the c axis (Figure c) in the polyhedral form. Topologically, the central Na(I) ion and the ligand are viewed as a uninodal 22-connected (390.4132.59) network (Figure d). The X-ray molecular structure of this complex has earlier been reported, but no crystal structure or graphical representations have been made or described earlier.

elements.content: The crystal structure of the [K(μ5 -L1)] n is totally different from an earlier reported structure of [K(μ-L1)(μ-L1H)] n , which is a 3D coordination polymer with the basic repeating [K(μ-L1)(μ-L1H)] moiety. Both L1 and L1H acted as a tetradentate ligands, connecting four K(I) ions, but their coordination modes were different being (μ4-κ4, η1:η1:η1:η1) for L1 and (μ4-κ5, η1:η1:η2:η1) for L1H. The present structure, however is also a 3D coordination polymer but with [K(μ5-L1)] n as the basic repeating unit and a coordination mode as (μ5-κ8,η1:η1:­η1:η1: η2:η2) (Scheme (ii)). The complex crystallizes in centrosymmetric C2/c space group with a 2-fold axis passing through the metal ion and the ligand L1 (). Each K(I) is eight-coordinated having symmetrical bidentate chelation through the carboxylate oxygens of one L1 and the nitro oxygens of the two symmetry related ligands (Figure a). Apart from behaving as a bidentate chelating group the carboxylate oxygens are also bridging between the two adjacent symmetry related K(I) ions along the c axis. This forms linear centrosymmetric chains of the KO8 edge sharing polyhedra with K···K nonbonding distances as 3.869 Å, running along the c axis (Figure b). Because of the bonding with the nitro groups, these chains form a 3D polymeric network (Figure c). Topologically, the structure consists of 3D framework with a uninodal 24-connected net having (3117.4154.55) point symbol for net (Figure d).

elements.content: Complex (III) is a 3D polymer () where each Cs(I) ion is nine coordinated in a distorted monocapped dodecahedral geometry (Figure a) by five symmetry related L1 ligands. Two ligands are coordinated through their carboxylate groups which bridge between two metal ions through only one of their oxygen atoms, i.e., O2; two ligands coordinate through one of the nitro oxygens, i.e., O4, while the fifth coordinates through one of its nitro oxygens O5 in a bridging mode between the two metal ions, following the (μ5-κ5, η2:η2:η1) (Scheme (iii)) coordination mode. The remaining three positions around the metal are occupied by three symmetry related, triply bridging water molecules O1W, while the second water of the asymmetric unit O2W terminally bonds only. This gives rise to a pair of polymeric chains of metal ions, bridged by water molecules, parallel to the b axis. Each polymeric chain in this pair consists of face sharing polyhedra (Figure b). The point symbol for the net is (351.449.55) where the net is 15-c, uninodal net having a new topology (Figure c,d).

elements.content: There are two similar but crystallographically independent [Na(μ-L2)·(H2O)2] monomeric units in the unit cell (). In each of the independent units Na(I) is bridged by four water molecules and a bidentate chelating L2 through carboxylate group. The two symmetry related water molecules O1W (or O3W) are almost trans to each other, whereas the remaining two symmetry related O2W (or O4W) have an angle of ∼101° on the metal ion. Though the coordination around each metal ion is six, the stereochemistry may be considered as TBP with two O1W (or O3W) water molecules occupying the axial positions and the two O2W (or O4W) lying on the equatorial positions and two chelating carboxylate oxygens O5, O6 (or O1, O14) being symmetrically disposed around the remaining third equatorial position. Each Na(I) ion in turn is attached to four symmetry related Na ions disposed nearly tetrahedrally around it due to these bridging water molecules (Figure a). The crystal structure shows stacking of the polymer down the b as well as c axes. This arrangement produces a pseudodiamondoid type network when viewed down the a axis (Figure b,c). The coordination mode in this complex is (μ-η1: η 1 ) (Scheme (iv)). Because of the bridging of two water molecules with single monomeric unit of the complex, one dimension chain is formed along the b axis. Topologically, both crystallographically independent units consist of pleated layers (1 0 0) with uninodal 4-connected net having (44.6 2 ) point symbol (Figure d). The two independent layers are attached to each other due to weak (C–H···O) H-bonding interactions.

elements.content: The unit cell contains three unique K(I) ions and three L2 anions (). All the three ligands use their carboxylate groups as well as one of the nitro groups for coordination toward the metal ions (Figure a). Thus, they behave as a chelating with bridging ligand giving a maximum of nine coordinate bonds. The carboxylate group of the first anionic ligand (O1 to O6) is bidentate chelating to K1 but bridges between K1 and K3 through O2 and between K2 and K3 through O1, while its nitro group bridges between K1 and K2 through oxygens O3 and O4 and forms a total of eight coordinate bonds (μ5-κ8, η3:η3:η1:η1) (b) (Scheme (v)). The second ligand (O7 to O12), employing its carboxylate group, chelates to K2 and bridging between two symmetry related K3 ions, using both O7 and O8, while O7 further bridges to a symmetry related K2 as well. Its nitro group bridges between two symmetry related K3 ions and K2 ion through O9 oxygen. It gives a total of nine coordinate bonds, whereas the carboxylate group of the third ligand (O13 to O18) forms seven bonds by chelation toward K2 ion and bidentate bridging between K3 and symmetry related K1 ions, through its carboxylate group while its nitro oxygen O15 bridges between K1 and K3 ions (μ5-κ7, η2:η3:η2 (Scheme (v))). This produces a 2D closed network as shown in the ab plane (Figure b). The metal–O (carboxylate) bonds are shorter than M–O (nitro) groups. The more important interactions in this framework are the M–O (carboxylates), with the latter acting as additional support and the framework remains intact in their absence as well. Topologically, the structure consists of layers (0 0 1) with 3-nodal (9, 14, 14-c) net with stoichiometry (9-c) (14-c) (14-c), where point symbol for net is (326.410) (340.441.510) (345.441.55). Point symbols for K1, K2, K3 metal ions are (340.441.510), (345.441.55), and (326.410) respectively (Figure c).

elements.content: Complex (VI) () is a 2D polymer where the carboxylate oxygen atoms are coordinated with the metal ion along with one of the oxygen atom of the nitro group at the ortho position. The Cs(I) metal ion is 10-coordinated, three sites occupied by oxygen atoms of nitro groups and seven sites by carboxylate oxygen atoms (Figure a). There are two types of L2 ligands: one is in the anionic form and other is in the protonated L2H form, having coordination modes μ6 and μ4 respectively. For the L2H, the carbonyl oxygen O1 is bridging bidentate and hydroxyl oxygen O2 and nitro oxygen O3 both act as monodentate. For the anionic form, O11 and O12 of the carboxylate group and O7 of the nitro group are bridging bidentate. Coordination modes are (μ4-κ6, η2:η2:η2) (a) and (μ3-κ4, η1:η2:η1) (b) (Scheme (vi)) responsible for 2D net in the bc plane (Figure b). Topologically, the structure consists of layers (1 0 0) with an 8-connected uninodal net with topology type SP 2-periodic net having the point symbol of (312.414.52) (Figure c).

elements.content: The repeating unit of this 2D polymer comprises one Ag(I), one L1 ligand which coordinates through the carboxylate as well as one of the nitro groups in (μ4-κ4, η1:η2:η1) (Scheme (vii)) mode of coordination. The carboxylate group behaves as a triply bridging group () through O5 and O6 atoms. Symmetrical bidentate bridging between two Ag(I) ions forms a centrosymmetric dimer with Ag–O5i = 2.164 (2) Å, Ag–O6 = 2.191(2) Å, respectively (i = −x, −y, −z). Further, such dimers are joined to each other through two long Ag–O6 2.708(2) Å bonds resulting in a ladder type 1D polymer, having alternate eight- and four-membered rings (Figure a) running along the a axis. The Ag···Ag distance in the two types of rings is 2.8887(4) Å and 3.4385(3) Å, respectively. Since the former is less than the sum of the van der Waals radii of two silver atoms (3.44 Å) and the latter is just equal to it, strong argentophilic {Ag2}2+ dimers exist in the eight-membered rings, which, along with two coordinating L1 molecules may be called as {Ag2L2} subunits. The four-membered ring is almost perpendicular to the {Ag2L2} ring resulting in the ladder formation. Furthermore, the nitro oxygen O3 criss crosses these ladders (Ag–O3 2.655(2) Å) to form a 2D “brick wall”-like framework (Figure b) in the ac plane. This structure is completely different than the earlier reported hydrated tetranuclear and anhydrous chain type structures of Ag(I) based complexes with L1, with noncoordinating nitro groups. Topologically, the structure consists of layers (0 1 0) with a uninodal 11-coordinated net having (327.426.52) point symbol (Figure c).

elements.content: [Cu(μ2-L1)2·(H2O)2] n (VIII) and [Cd(μ2-L1)2·(H2O)2] n (IX) complexes are isomorphous and isostructural, which is confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (). Therefore, only that of the copper complex is discussed in detail. The coordination environment of [Cu(μ2-L1)2·(H2O)2] n shows that each Cu(II) atom is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygens from two unique L1 groups and two water molecules forming a square planar arrangement with Cu–O2 = 1.937 (3), Cu–O8 = 1.950(3) Å, Cu–O1W = 1.950(3) Å, Cu–O2W = 1.948(3) Å. In the axial position, two very long bonds are formed by the remaining two carboxylate oxygens of the two symmetry related L1 molecules with Cu–O1 2.532(3) and Cu–O7 = 2.665(3) Å. This gives a “z out” kind of tetragonal distortion around copper(II) ion (Figure a) using (μ2-η1:η1) (Scheme (viii)) coordination mode. The arrangement results in the formation of a chiral, double helical (Figure b) 1D coordination polymer (Figure c), propagating parallel to the b axis, and a Cu···Cu nonbonding distance of 4.701 Å. In both the L1 molecules, the −COO group is rotated with respect to the phenyl ring by ∼22°, which takes them out of the plane from the phenyl ring resulting in this unsymmetrical bridging between two metal ions, which yields a completely different structure than the typical paddle-wheel structure found in copper(II) acetate monohydrate complex and also in the dimeric complexes of L1 and L2 with Cu (II) ion (vide infra). The crystal structure of (VIII) comprises intermolecular hydrogen bonding due to the presence of two coordinated water molecules O1W and O2W. Both nitro groups of ligand participate in the intermolecular H-bonding interactions responsible for the 2D structure of complex shown in the ac plane (Figure d). Each water molecule acts as a double H-bond donor toward one nitro group from each DNB, whereas the second nitro group forms one H-bond each with the phenylene group. Topologically, both (VIII) and (IX) consist of chains [0 1 0] with 2-connected uninodal net.

[Cu(μ2-L1)2⋅(H2O)2] n (VIII) and [Cd(μ2-L1)2⋅(H2O)2] n  (IX) complexes are isomorphous and isostructural, which is confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (). Therefore, only that of the copper complex is discussed in detail. The coordination environment of [Cu(μ2-L1)2⋅(H2O)2] n  shows that each Cu(II) atom is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygens from two unique L1 groups and two water molecules forming a square planar arrangement with Cu-O2 = 1.937 (3), Cu-O8 = 1.950(3) Å, Cu-O1W = 1.950(3) Å, Cu-O2W = 1.948(3) Å. In the axial position, two very long bonds are formed by the remaining two carboxylate oxygens of the two symmetry related L1 molecules with Cu-O1 2.532(3) and Cu-O7 = 2.665(3) Å. This gives a "z out" kind of tetragonal distortion around copper(II) ion (Figure a) using (μ2-η1:η1) (Scheme (viii)) coordination mode. The arrangement results in the formation of a chiral, double helical (Figure b) 1D coordination polymer (Figure c), propagating parallel to the b axis, and a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu nonbonding distance of 4.701 Å. In both the L1 molecules, the -COO group is rotated with respect to the phenyl ring by ~22°, which takes them out of the plane from the phenyl ring resulting in this unsymmetrical bridging between two metal ions, which yields a completely different structure than the typical paddle-wheel structure found in copper(II) acetate monohydrate complex and also in the dimeric complexes of L1 and L2 with Cu (II) ion (vide infra). The crystal structure of (VIII) comprises intermolecular hydrogen bonding due to the presence of two coordinated water molecules O1W and O2W. Both nitro groups of ligand participate in the intermolecular H-bonding interactions responsible for the 2D structure of complex shown in the ac plane (Figure d). Each water molecule acts as a double H-bond donor toward one nitro group from each DNB, whereas the second nitro group forms one H-bond each with the phenylene group. Topologically, both (VIII) and (IX) consist of chains [0 1 0] with 2-connected uninodal net.

elements.content: The structure of [Zn(μ2-L1)2] n (X) complex () is 1D polymeric double helical, which is already reported in the literature, but no description of the crystal structure was given. The complex crystallizes in P3121 enantiomorphic space group. Each Zn(II) ion is tetrahedrally coordinated (Figure a) by four carboxylate oxygen atoms O1, O2 from four different 3,5-DNB ligands showing (μ2-η1: η 1 ) (Scheme (viii)) type of coordination mode. Each L1 behaves as a bidentate, slightly unsymmetrical bridging ligand through the carboxylate group only in the 1D polymeric complex (Figure b) forming a double helical chain parallel to the c axis (Figure c). The crystal structure shows stacking down the c axis. The structure consists of chains [0 0 1] with 2-c net, uninodal net. Unlike the Na(μ6-L1) complex, however, the nonparticipation of the nitro groups in the coordination precludes any possibility of a 3D crystal structure due to coordination polymerization.

elements.content: The molecule crystallizes in tetragonal P4/ncc space group. The asymmetric unit of the molecule contains one Ag(I) ion and one L2 anion along with 0.25 of a water molecule (). The moiety formula of the complex is {[Ag(μ3-L2)]4·H2O}, which is the repeat unit in this polymer. The carboxylate oxygen O1 from four L2 ligands and four Ag(I) ions forms a pseudocubane-like architecture (Figure a) about the 4-fold axis. The mode of coordination of L2 is (μ3-κ3, η1:η2) (Scheme (ix)). Each O1 is bonded to two Ag(I) ions and each Ag(I) ion is bonded to two symmetry related O1 atoms. Third coordination position about the Ag(I) ions is occupied by the carboxylate oxygen O2 of yet another L2 moiety. O2 bridges between two successive cubane type motifs, with Ag–O1 2.241 (2), Agi–O1 2.412 (2) and Ag–O2ii 2.171 (2) Å, (i = −y + 1, x – 1/2, −z + 1, ii = y + 1/2, x – 1/2, −z + 3/2). Two types of argentophilic interactions occur in the crystal structure, Ag–Agii is 2.827(6) Å and Ag–Agiii is 3.202(7) Å (iii = −x + 3/2, −y + 1/2, z). The former, along with carboxylate oxygens, completes an almost square planar environment around each Ag(I) and the latter, rather longer interactions join two such units related by the 4-fold axis, completing square pyramid coordination around each Ag(I). These argentophilic interactions thus form {Ag4L4} subunits as the repeat units in this crystal. The overall arrangement produces a skewed, 1D coordination polymer about the 4-fold axis parallel to the c axis. The crystal structure forms channels parallel to the c axis which contains a disordered lattice water (Figure b), placed at the 4-fold axis. This water is H-bonded with the nitro oxygen O6 and phenylene C4 surrounding it. Topologically, the structure consists of chains [0 0 1] having a 7-coordinated uninodal net with point symbol (312.48.5).

elements.content: This complex is 1D polymeric () crystallizing in noncentrosymmetric P21 space group, with the ligand in a (μ3-κ3, η1:η2) (Scheme (ix)) mode of coordination. In this tetra-coordinated Li(I) complex, three sites of Li(I) ion are occupied by carboxylate oxygen atoms of three different L2 ligands, and the remaining one site is occupied by the oxygen atom of the water molecule (Figure a). Thus, double helical polymeric chains are formed parallel to the b axis as shown in Figure b,c; the Li···Li nonbonding distance is 2.975(3) Å and various Li–O distances are Li–O1 = 1.903(3) Å, Li–O1i = 1.979(3) Å, Li–O2 = 1.914(3) Å, Li–O1W = 2.005(3) Å. Topologically, the structure consists of chains [0 1 0] with a 4-coordinated uninodal net with point symbol for the net of (33.42.5).

elements.content: XIII is a 1D polymeric complex crystallizing in the C2/c centrosymmetric space group (). In this hepta coordinated complex of Ca(II), six sites are occupied by the carboxylate oxygen of six different L1 ligands, and the remaining position is occupied by oxygen atom of water molecule (Figure a). The mode of coordination is (μ3-κ3, η1:η2) (Scheme (ix)). Each carboxylate group behaves as a tridentate bridging ligand and coordinates to three consecutive Ca(II) ions. It is acting as a bridging bidentate ligand between two Ca(II) ions through O1, O2 and O7, O8 oxygens showing -μ3 - mode of binding, whereas O1 and O7 are further bridging to the next Ca(II) ion. This gives rise to two intertwined, mutually perpendicular, centrosymmetric corrugated tapes of eight-membered rings, which are joined by O1 and O7 carboxylate oxygens. The tube thus formed runs parallel to the b axis as shown in Figure b,c. The stereochemistry around Ca(II) may be considered as a distorted capped octahedron. Ca···Ca nonbonding distances are alternating between 3.566(1) and 3.609(1) Å. Intermolecular hydrogen bonding between water and nitro oxygens O4 and O11 extends this 1D polymer into 2D H-bonded polymer in the ac plane (O1W···O11i = 2.974(5) Å, O1W···O4ii 3.139(6) Å, i = −x + 1/2 + 1, +y + 1/2, −z + 1/2, ii = −x + 1, −y, −z) (Figure d). Topologically, the structure consists of chains [0 1 0] with a 4-coordinated uninodal net having point symbol for net of (33.42.5).

elements.content: (XIV) () is a 1D polymer, in centrosymmetric space group C2/c. The metal ion is 10 coordinated, where eight sites are occupied by O atoms of carboxylate groups from six ligands and two sites by two acetonitrile solvent molecules (Figure a). The coordination modes of L1 anion and HL1 ligands are different, i.e., (μ2-κ3, η1:η2) (Scheme (xa) and (μ1-κ1, η1) (Scheme (xb), respectively). The carboxylate groups of L1 ligands act as tridentate chelating-with-bridging groups, whereas the carboxylic acid HL1 coordinates in a monodentate mode through the carbonyl group of the acid (O1) only. The O8 carboxylate oxygen of L1 anion unsymmetrically bridges between the two consecutive metal ions with bond distances 2.695(1) and 3.208(1) Å. The Ba–O7 distance is 2.796(1) Å and Ba–O1 distance is 2.995(1) Å. The linear, centrosymmetric, 1D tape thus formed, along the b axis has a Ba···Ba nonbonding distance of 4.870(1) Å (Figure b). Topologically, the structure consist of chains [0 1 0] with 2-connected uninodal net.

elements.content: Both inter- and intramolecular H-bonding are present in the crystal structure, assisting the coordination bonding in the formation of a 3D network, shown in the ac plane (Figure c). The strong intermolecular H-bonding between the −OH group (O2) of HL1 and the carboxyl group (O7) of L1 forms an acid salt () and within two solvent molecules (C16···N5) support the formation of the 1D polymer. Three weak H-bonding interactions between the methyl group of the solvent and the nitro oxygen O3 and one between the phenylene C4 and the nitro O10 extend the crystal structure along the c and a axis, respectively. The intermolecular hydrogen bonding is observed between the methyl group of acetonitrile with the O3 atom of the nitro group ().

elements.content: Both complexes (XV) and (XVI) have a typical paddle-wheel type structure (), having a dihedral angle of 88.25° and 70.70° between the two coordination planes (Figure a,b), and Cu···Cu distances are 2.6263(4) and 2.665(4) Å respectively. The average Cu–O distance in the symmetrically bridged structures is 1.973(1) Å. The Cu–O (water) distances are 2.135(1) and 2.131(1) Å, respectively. It is worth noticing that the −COO group here is not rotated with respect to the phenyl ring (dihedral angle only 2°) unlike that found in (VIII) (vide supra), resulting in a symmetrical bridging. The binding modes in both the dimeric complexes are also the same, i.e., (μ2-η1: η1). The difference lies only in the crystal packing of them. Because of the presence of acetonitrile solvent in the lattice of complex (XV), H-bonding interactions are strong. First the O1W water molecule forms intermolecular H-bonding with the carboxylate oxygens O1 and O8 () which supported by C14···O1 interaction forms a 1D H-bonded chains of these dimeric molecules, running parallel to the b axis (Figure c). These chains in turn interact with each other due to C5–H5···O9, phenylene, and nitro groups H-bonding, resulting in a H-bonded 2D structure, in the ac plane. The acetonitrile molecules are in the voids created in this 2D structure and remain there due to O1W–H2W···N5 H-bonding interactions between the water molecule and the acetonitrile (Figure d). Removal of these acetonitrile molecules from the lattice yields voids as shown in complex (XV) (Figure e). In the case of complex (XVI), carboxylate oxygens O2 and O7 and nitro oxygens O6 and O12 are H-bonded with hydrogens of coordinated water molecules () (Figure f). Because of these strong H-bonding interactions, corrugated chains are connected with each other as shown in the ab plane (Figure g).

Crystal Structures of Dimeric Complexes

[Cu(μ2-L1)2⋅(H2O)]2(C2H3N)2 (XV) and [Cu(μ2-L2)2⋅(H2O)]2 (XVI) Complex

Both complexes (XV) and (XVI) have a typical paddle-wheel type structure (), having a dihedral angle of 88.25° and 70.70° between the two coordination planes (Figure a,b), and Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are 2.6263(4) and 2.665(4) Å respectively. The average Cu-O distance in the symmetrically bridged structures is 1.973(1) Å. The Cu-O (water) distances are 2.135(1) and 2.131(1) Å, respectively. It is worth noticing that the -COO group here is not rotated with respect to the phenyl ring (dihedral angle only 2°) unlike that found in (VIII) (vide supra), resulting in a symmetrical bridging. The binding modes in both the dimeric complexes are also the same, i.e., (μ2-η1: η1). The difference lies only in the crystal packing of them. Because of the presence of acetonitrile solvent in the lattice of complex (XV), H-bonding interactions are strong. First the O1W water molecule forms intermolecular H-bonding with the carboxylate oxygens O1 and O8 () which supported by C14⋅⋅⋅O1 interaction forms a 1D H-bonded chains of these dimeric molecules, running parallel to the b axis (Figure c). These chains in turn interact with each other due to C5-H5⋅⋅⋅O9, phenylene, and nitro groups H-bonding, resulting in a H-bonded 2D structure, in the ac plane. The acetonitrile molecules are in the voids created in this 2D structure and remain there due to O1W-H2W⋅⋅⋅N5 H-bonding interactions between the water molecule and the acetonitrile (Figure d). Removal of these acetonitrile molecules from the lattice yields voids as shown in complex (XV) (Figure e). In the case of complex (XVI), carboxylate oxygens O2 and O7 and nitro oxygens O6 and O12 are H-bonded with hydrogens of coordinated water molecules () (Figure f). Because of these strong H-bonding interactions, corrugated chains are connected with each other as shown in the ab plane (Figure g).

elements.content: The thermal stability of complexes was examined by TGA (Figure ). The curves of complexes (I), (II), and (V) show that they are stable up to 270, 370, and 270 °C, respectively. (II) and (V) explode beyond that whereas (I) starts decomposing after 270 °C, in three steps and explodes above 410 °C. The complex (III) is stable up to 95 °C at which it loses one coordinated water molecule (weight loss 4.24%, calcd 4.77%), and at 235 °C it loses another coordinated water molecule (weight loss 5.06%, calcd 4.70%), beyond that it is stable up to 273 °C where it finally decomposes with explosion. The complex (IV) is stable up to 80 °C at which it loses two coordinated water molecules (weight loss 13.80%, calcd. 13.34%), and beyond that it is stable up to 330 °C where it finally decomposes with an explosion. Complex (VI) is stable up to 367 °C and decomposes in single step beyond this. Complex (VII) decomposes in two steps starting from 270 °C leaving Ag residue at 321 °C (weight loss 66.68%, calcd 66.46%). On the other hand complex (XI) shows decomposition in two steps with the loss of one lattice water molecule at 170 °C (weight loss 1.38%, calcd 1.67%), and then it simply blows up 252 °C. Thermal decomposition curves of (VIII) and (IX) are approximately similar, as both are having two coordinated water molecules in the polymeric crystal structure. Both of them lose two coordinated water molecules at 170 °C (for (VIII), weight loss 6.99%, calcd 6.88%; for (IX) the weight loss is 6.33%, calcd 6.30%). Beyond that both of them blow up at 330 °C. The complex (X) is highly stable up to 410 °C, and beyond that it goes off in a single step. The complex (XII) is stable up to 207 °C at which it loses one coordinated water molecule (weight loss 8.08%, calcd 7.62%), and beyond that it finally it decomposes at 281 °C. Thermal decomposition of (XIII) shows loss of one coordinated water molecule at 200 °C (weight loss 3.66%, calcd 3.75%). Beyond that the complex is stable up to 400 °C where it goes off. The TGA curve of (XIV) shows the loss of coordinated acetonitrile solvent molecules at 180 °C (weight loss 7.2%, calcd. 7.6%). After that it blows up at 400 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stability of complexes was examined by TGA (Figure ). The curves of complexes (I), (II), and (V) show that they are stable up to 270, 370, and 270 °C, respectively. (II) and (V) explode beyond that whereas (I) starts decomposing after 270 °C, in three steps and explodes above 410 °C. The complex (III) is stable up to 95 °C at which it loses one coordinated water molecule (weight loss 4.24%, calcd 4.77%), and at 235 °C it loses another coordinated water molecule (weight loss 5.06%, calcd 4.70%), beyond that it is stable up to 273 °C where it finally decomposes with explosion. The complex (IV) is stable up to 80 °C at which it loses two coordinated water molecules (weight loss 13.80%, calcd. 13.34%), and beyond that it is stable up to 330 °C where it finally decomposes with an explosion. Complex (VI) is stable up to 367 °C and decomposes in single step beyond this. Complex (VII) decomposes in two steps starting from 270 °C leaving Ag residue at 321 °C (weight loss 66.68%, calcd 66.46%). On the other hand complex (XI) shows decomposition in two steps with the loss of one lattice water molecule at 170 °C (weight loss 1.38%, calcd 1.67%), and then it simply blows up 252 °C. Thermal decomposition curves of (VIII) and (IX) are approximately similar, as both are having two coordinated water molecules in the polymeric crystal structure. Both of them lose two coordinated water molecules at 170 °C (for (VIII), weight loss 6.99%, calcd 6.88%; for (IX) the weight loss is 6.33%, calcd 6.30%). Beyond that both of them blow up at 330 °C. The complex (X) is highly stable up to 410 °C, and beyond that it goes off in a single step. The complex (XII) is stable up to 207 °C at which it loses one coordinated water molecule (weight loss 8.08%, calcd 7.62%), and beyond that it finally it decomposes at 281 °C. Thermal decomposition of (XIII) shows loss of one coordinated water molecule at 200 °C (weight loss 3.66%, calcd 3.75%). Beyond that the complex is stable up to 400 °C where it goes off. The TGA curve of (XIV) shows the loss of coordinated acetonitrile solvent molecules at 180 °C (weight loss 7.2%, calcd. 7.6%). After that it blows up at 400 °C.

elements.content: All of the complexes are of dinitrobenzoates which are expected to explode at a certain temperature, but this temperature has been seen to vary in different complexes. The thermal stability of complexes may be related to the dimensionality of the complex. For example, 3D polymeric complexes (Table ) have been found to decompose at high temperature which is >350 °C (except for (III)), while 2D complexes (except for (VI)) decompose at ∼270 °C, respectively. The exceptional behavior of (III) may be attributed to the fact that unlike (I) and (II), there are two water molecules which contribute to its 3D arrangement, while the extraordinary thermal stability of (VI) may be a result of its uniqueness, being an acid salt of L2, with no solvent in it. The presence of solvent molecules in the crystal has mostly led to the formation of a 1D polymer, and they are lost at a fairly high temperature range of 170–200 °C. After their loss, further decomposition with explosion is seen to occur at a relatively high temperature > 330 °C (except for XI). The latter in many cases is even higher than the decomposition temperature of the 2D coordination polymers. It may be due to higher dimensionality of the crystal structures formed on loss of a coordinated solvent, probably using the available −NO2 groups. This, in other words, means that solvent molecules compete for the coordination with the −NO2 groups, especially in the alkali and alkaline earth metal ions. The solvent molecules in these 1D polymers are lost at relatively higher temperature >170 °C, which again indicates their strong tendency for coordination. This is especially true for Ca(II) complex (XIII) (loss of water 200 °C) which may be partially due to its high hydration energy. Exceptionally high thermal stability of 1D complex (X) of Zn(II) may be attributed to its double helical structure sans solvent.

Isostructural complexes (VIII) and (IX) have identical TGA plots signifying the correlation of the type of bonding on the thermal stability. On comparing a similar paddle-wheel, dimeric complexes of Cu(II), after the loss of solvent molecules (XV) have a significantly higher decomposition temperature than (XVI). This observation follows a general trend found in this study that the alkali metal ions and Ag(I) complexes of L1 are found to be more stable and of higher dimensionality than from L2 with the same metal ion. For example, AgL1 (VII) is 2D whereas AgL2 (XI) is a 1D polymer, and similarly complexes of Na(I), K(I), and Cs(I) with L1 (I to III) are 3D, while those with L2 (IV to VI) are 2D. Not only this, these complexes of L1 have a decomposition temperature much higher than their L2 counterparts (except for (VI)). This difference in their thermal stability and dimensionality is incidentally related to the participation of −NO2 groups in the coordination. For example, (I) to (III) have complete and (VII) has partial participation of −NO2 groups in coordination process, whereas their counterparts (IV) to (VI) and (XI) have either no participation or partial participation of −NO2 groups in the coordination. The lesser propensity of the −NO2 group of L2 to take part in coordination may be attributed to the disposition of the −NO2 group ortho to the −CO2 group, which causes steric hindrance when coordinating to smaller metal ions such Na(I) and Ag(I), while it is able to extend that coordination (partially) to larger metal ions such as K(I) and Cs(I). The discussion may be extended by including and reviewing some already known complexes of L1 and L2 (Table ). For example, two complexes of Ag(I) with L1 are 1D with no coordination from −NO2 groups, while its complex with K(I) is 3D, with coordinating nitro groups. However, the small Li(I) ion gives 1D polymers with both L1 and L2, hinting toward the significant role of the size of the metal ions. The transition metal ions give either monomers or 1D polymers following their crystal field energy requirements.

elements.content: For (XV), CuL1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system in the centrosymmetric P21/n space group. It has a typical paddle-wheel structure of dimeric copper(II) acetate monohydrate with acetonitrile in the lattice. Complex (XV) on losing acetonitrile gave (VIII) which crystallizes in an orthorhombic chiral, Pna21 space group and is an extended 1D polymer. Both crystals were characterized by single crystal X-diffraction. The unit cell of (XV) is slightly bigger than (VIII). A deliberate attempt to heat the crystals to (XV) at 50 °C and remeasuring its single crystal X-ray diffraction yields (VIII) only, which was also confirmed by PXRD of the heated sample (). After heating of (XV) the new (VIII) obtained shows some expansion of its cell with 0.022 Å, 0.0018 Å, 0.026, and 5.2 Å3 increase in a, b, c, and V, respectively. Regrowing or soaking the crystals of (VIII) in acetonitrile does not yield back (XV). This shows that this heat and desolvation induced solid phase supramolecular isomerization of phases is irreversible and probably (XV) is the kinetically stable, transient product which ultimately transforms into thermodynamically stable form (VIII).
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal-to-Crystal Transformation of Dimeric Form to 1-D Polymeric Form of Cu(II) Complex

For (XV), CuL1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system in the centrosymmetric P21/n space group. It has a typical paddle-wheel structure of dimeric copper(II) acetate monohydrate with acetonitrile in the lattice. Complex (XV) on losing acetonitrile gave (VIII) which crystallizes in an orthorhombic chiral, Pna21 space group and is an extended 1D polymer. Both crystals were characterized by single crystal X-diffraction. The unit cell of (XV) is slightly bigger than (VIII). A deliberate attempt to heat the crystals to (XV) at 50 °C and remeasuring its single crystal X-ray diffraction yields (VIII) only, which was also confirmed by PXRD of the heated sample (). After heating of (XV) the new (VIII) obtained shows some expansion of its cell with 0.022 Å, 0.0018 Å, 0.026, and 5.2 Å3 increase in a, b, c, and V, respectively. Regrowing or soaking the crystals of (VIII) in acetonitrile does not yield back (XV). This shows that this heat and desolvation induced solid phase supramolecular isomerization of phases is irreversible and probably (XV) is the kinetically stable, transient product which ultimately transforms into thermodynamically stable form (VIII).

elements.content: Luminescence properties of free ligands L1 and L2 and their complexes with different metal ions were studied in the DMSO solution state at room temperature. The UV absorption spectra of free ligands L1 and L2 exhibit weak absorption bands at 275 and 299 nm respectively (), which are usually attributed to ligand to ligand (LLCT) or π–π* or n−π* transitions. Upon excitation at 275 nm, free L1 exhibits broad, almost negligible emission bands at λmax 349 nm, whereas L2 is totally nonemissive. The band in the former case has been tentatively attributed to the π*−π transition. Many aromatic ligands which include some polycarboxylate ligands also are weakly or nonemissive themselves, but their complexes show strong luminescence. The fluorescent emission bands are observed in the region of λmax 327–330 nm for L1 complexes (II), (VIII), (XIII), and (XIV) (ex = 272–276 nm), while L2 complexes (IV),(V),(IX), (XI), and (XVI) (ex = 272–298 nm) give fluorescent emission bands in the region of λmax 357–380 nm (Figure a,b). The results of their luminescent studies are given in Figure c, which show a significant response to Cu(II) ions. In the complexes these emissions might come from aforementioned LLCT, π–π* or n−π* transitions or may originate from LMCT or MLCT transitions. Except for Cu (II) complexes (VIII) and (XVI), the observed luminescence has been observed in complexes of Na(I), K(I), Ca(II), Ba(II), Cd(II), and Ag(I), all of which are difficult to oxidize or reduce; therefore these emissions have been assigned as intraligand transitions. The absorption bands in L1 are relatively at higher energy than L2 (vide supra), which is consistent with the HOMO–LUMO energy gap calculated in the two cases theoretically (ΔE = 3.430 eV in L1 and 3.318 eV in L2) (). Accordingly the emission bands for L1 complexes are consistently at higher energies than those for L2. In the Cu(II) complexes, there is a possibility of LMCT or MLCT, but as the energy and shape of the observed bands are similar to that seen in the case of nontransition metal ions therefore they have been ruled out in favor of intraligand transitions only. The nonemissive nature of free ligands in solution is caused by the excessive loss of energy due to radiation-less decay in the nonrigid molecules. After complexation the rigidity conferred by the metal ion and the crystal structure largely reduces this decay and results in the enhancement of photoluminescence intensity. The fact that almost half of the studied complexes showed no luminescence may be attributed to the difference in nature of the encapsulated/coordinated solvent molecules, crystal packing, and nature of metal clusters. In fact a closer look at the photoluminiscent complexes shows that except for the K(I) complexes (II) and (V) the rest of them have water/solvent in them which is bound to affect the crystal structures by increasing the noncovalent interactions manifolds. The most significant photoluminescence is seen in the case of polymeric copper(II) complex (VIII) which has an intensity way higher than the other complexes. Many fluorescent complexes of Cu (II) have been reported, and it has been found by DFT calculations also that the luminescence in copper(II) complexes is a result of mixing of LMCT and LLCT. A relatively large intensity of the emission band in (VIII) may be attributed to such an event here as well. This is further supported by the fact that the isomorphous and isostructural Cd (II) complex (IX) has much less intensity than (VIII). Most of the times transition metal ions decrease the emission intensity of complexes by allowing the forbidden intersystem crossing (ISC) from S1 to T1 state resulting in paramagnetic fluorescence quenching, which is called the chelation enhanced quenching (CHEQ) effect. However, presently in the complex (VIII), there is a large increase in the intensity of emission band compared to the free ligand L1 and a reasonable response for (XVI) of L2. This “turn on” of luminescence could be identified as the chelation enhanced fluorescence effect (CHEF), in (XVI) and a combination of CHEF and facilitated LLCT transition in (VIII), which may be attributed to a more rigid 3D crystal structure of (VIII).

elements.content: In this work, we have reported 17 complexes, using different alkali, alkaline, and transition metal ions with positional isomers L1 and L2 and studied them from a crystal engineering point of view. Their X-ray crystal structures unfold a plethora of coordination modes and supramolecular architectures being created. Commencing from 0D monomers and paddle-wheel dimers to pseudocubane, double helices, ladders, and linear 1D tapes to pseudodiamondoid and brick-wall type 2D to chiral 3D networks, the nitro benzoates offer versatility, novelty, and thermal stability in inorganic–organic hybrids. Combining our observations with those found in the literature, it has been seen that the engineering of a particular architecture for these ligands depends on the conformation of the ligand, disposition and participation of −NO2 groups and nature and size of the metal ion. The nonemissive ligands show a medium amount of photoluminescence with some d10 and p6 metal ions, which has been attributed to the rigidity of the ligand in the crystal structure, cutting on radiationless decay, enhancing the photoluminescence. A relatively much larger luminescence in the case of polymeric complex of Cu(II) results from a combination of CHEF and facilitated LLCT transition owing to the rigidity of L1 in a double helical 1D crystal structure. A single crystal to crystal transformation, showing supramolecular isomerism from a H-bonded, solvated paddle-wheel dimeric structure to a 1D polymer. The transformation is triggered by the loss of lattice solvent and change in conformation of the ligand. In some cases single, double, and triple helical 3D and 1D chains have been formed, which is very interesting since infinite helical structural motifs have an important role in biological systems, enantioselective catalysis, and nonlinear optics.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we have reported 17 complexes, using different alkali, alkaline, and transition metal ions with positional isomers L1 and L2 and studied them from a crystal engineering point of view. Their X-ray crystal structures unfold a plethora of coordination modes and supramolecular architectures being created. Commencing from 0D monomers and paddle-wheel dimers to pseudocubane, double helices, ladders, and linear 1D tapes to pseudodiamondoid and brick-wall type 2D to chiral 3D networks, the nitro benzoates offer versatility, novelty, and thermal stability in inorganic-organic hybrids. Combining our observations with those found in the literature, it has been seen that the engineering of a particular architecture for these ligands depends on the conformation of the ligand, disposition and participation of -NO2 groups and nature and size of the metal ion. The nonemissive ligands show a medium amount of photoluminescence with some d10 and p6 metal ions, which has been attributed to the rigidity of the ligand in the crystal structure, cutting on radiationless decay, enhancing the photoluminescence. A relatively much larger luminescence in the case of polymeric complex of Cu(II) results from a combination of CHEF and facilitated LLCT transition owing to the rigidity of L1 in a double helical 1D crystal structure. A single crystal to crystal transformation, showing supramolecular isomerism from a H-bonded, solvated paddle-wheel dimeric structure to a 1D polymer. The transformation is triggered by the loss of lattice solvent and change in conformation of the ligand. In some cases single, double, and triple helical 3D and 1D chains have been formed, which is very interesting since infinite helical structural motifs have an important role in biological systems, enantioselective catalysis, and nonlinear optics.

L1 (3,5-DNB) or L2 (2,4-DNB) (1 mmol, 0.21 g) was suspended in a moderate volume of acetonitrile. An aqueous solution of M2CO3 (i.e., Na2CO3, K2CO3, Li2CO3, Cs2CO3) (1 mmol) was added dropwise to this solution and stirred overnight at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to slowly evaporate to give colorless crystals within 1 week (70–78% yield). M.p. > 300 °C.

General Procedure

General Procedure for Synthesis of Complexes (I), (II), (III), (IV), (V), (VI), (XII)

 L1 (3,5-DNB) or L2 (2,4-DNB) (1 mmol, 0.21 g) was suspended in a moderate volume of acetonitrile. An aqueous solution of M2CO3 (i.e., Na2CO3, K2CO3, Li2CO3, Cs2CO3) (1 mmol) was added dropwise to this solution and stirred overnight at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to slowly evaporate to give colorless crystals within 1 week (70-78% yield). M.p. > 300 °C.

Anal. Calcd for (VIII), C 14 H 10 CuN 4 O 14 (%): C, 33.23; H, 1.69; N, 11.17; Found: C, 33.50; H, 1.67; N, 11.64. IR (cm–1) selected bonds: υ = 3447 (b) (O–H), 3095 (w) (Ar–H), 1637 (s) (COO–)asy, 1466 (m) (COO–)sy, 1344 (s) (N–O), 1076 (m) (C–O), 536 (w) (M–O).

[Li(μ<sub>3</sub>-L2)·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>XII</bold>)

This complex is 1D polymeric () crystallizing in noncentrosymmetric P21 space group, with the ligand in a (μ3-κ3, η1:η2) (Scheme (ix)) mode of coordination. In this tetra-coordinated Li(I) complex, three sites of Li(I) ion are occupied by carboxylate oxygen atoms of three different L2 ligands, and the remaining one site is occupied by the oxygen atom of the water molecule (Figure a). Thus, double helical polymeric chains are formed parallel to the b axis as shown in Figure b,c; the Li···Li nonbonding distance is 2.975(3) Å and various Li–O distances are Li–O1 = 1.903(3) Å, Li–O1i = 1.979(3) Å, Li–O2 = 1.914(3) Å, Li–O1W = 2.005(3) Å. Topologically, the structure consists of chains [0 1 0] with a 4-coordinated uninodal net with point symbol for the net of (33.42.5).

Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stability of complexes was examined by TGA (Figure ). The curves of complexes (I), (II), and (V) show that they are stable up to 270, 370, and 270 °C, respectively. (II) and (V) explode beyond that whereas (I) starts decomposing after 270 °C, in three steps and explodes above 410 °C. The complex (III) is stable up to 95 °C at which it loses one coordinated water molecule (weight loss 4.24%, calcd 4.77%), and at 235 °C it loses another coordinated water molecule (weight loss 5.06%, calcd 4.70%), beyond that it is stable up to 273 °C where it finally decomposes with explosion. The complex (IV) is stable up to 80 °C at which it loses two coordinated water molecules (weight loss 13.80%, calcd. 13.34%), and beyond that it is stable up to 330 °C where it finally decomposes with an explosion. Complex (VI) is stable up to 367 °C and decomposes in single step beyond this. Complex (VII) decomposes in two steps starting from 270 °C leaving Ag residue at 321 °C (weight loss 66.68%, calcd 66.46%). On the other hand complex (XI) shows decomposition in two steps with the loss of one lattice water molecule at 170 °C (weight loss 1.38%, calcd 1.67%), and then it simply blows up 252 °C. Thermal decomposition curves of (VIII) and (IX) are approximately similar, as both are having two coordinated water molecules in the polymeric crystal structure. Both of them lose two coordinated water molecules at 170 °C (for (VIII), weight loss 6.99%, calcd 6.88%; for (IX) the weight loss is 6.33%, calcd 6.30%). Beyond that both of them blow up at 330 °C. The complex (X) is highly stable up to 410 °C, and beyond that it goes off in a single step. The complex (XII) is stable up to 207 °C at which it loses one coordinated water molecule (weight loss 8.08%, calcd 7.62%), and beyond that it finally it decomposes at 281 °C. Thermal decomposition of (XIII) shows loss of one coordinated water molecule at 200 °C (weight loss 3.66%, calcd 3.75%). Beyond that the complex is stable up to 400 °C where it goes off. The TGA curve of (XIV) shows the loss of coordinated acetonitrile solvent molecules at 180 °C (weight loss 7.2%, calcd. 7.6%). After that it blows up at 400 °C.

Complex (XV) shows loss of two acetonitrile solvent molecules from lattice at 139 °C (weight loss 7.35%, calcd 7.53%). It loses two coordinated water molecules up to 167 °C (weight loss 3.67%, calcd 3.30%) and finally blows up at 370 °C. The TGA graph of dimeric complex (XVI) shows the loss of two coordinated water molecules (weight loss 3.30%, calcd 3.57%) up to 190 °C and complete decomposition at 290 °C. Complex (XVII) starts losing weight at 110 °C giving away four lattice water molecules (weight loss 12.91%, calcd 12.19%) followed by the loss of four coordinated water molecules (weight 11.11%, calcd 12.31%) at 180 °C and subsequently a complete decomposition above 280 °C.
